captions.text: [music]
kpopisawesome123 from Texas asks
what is the worst mistake you made in Korea
So technically the question about "can you do a house tour" was the winner,
but we plan on doing a house tour this weekend
so we're going to do the next top rated question
which is something like four pages in
because everyone wants to see our apartment
Yeah, don't worry, we'll show you.
Ok, so what was the worst mistake we did while in Korea Simon?
I think they are from restaurants,
we did a lot of restaurant mistakes when we first came here.
So we picked this tiny little restaurant in our neighbourhood
and we looked around and there were like grills and it looked like
there was chicken on the menu, yeah, I thought it was going to be
grilling chicken which was awesome because I love chicken
right, so we're like looking at the pictures because we can't read yet
and we're like this is it, we're going to go here,
we're going to do it, we like, pumped ourselves up
we were like, UGH! LET'S DO THIS! UHHHH! WE'RE GONNA GET CHICKEN!
MEAT! WE'RE GONNA GRILL IT! MEAT! UHHH! *CAVEMAN SOUNDS* MEAT!!!!
So we go to the restaurant and we point to the picture
and we're like, yeah, we want that one, he's like, "okay"
so we sit down at our table, and he brings out all our water,
our drinks, he brings out all these side dishes,
like lots and lots of banchan (<--side dishes in Korean)
and then he brings out the meat which turns out wasn't chicken.
It was actually pig's fat--yes--skin,
and then dangly fat and not even a little bit of meat.
No protein at all. No. So we're like, you know what, that's okay.
We'll give it a shot. (We'll give it a shot) We're experimental.
Probably tastes like delicious bacon or something...probably.
So we started grilling it and the meat is attacking us, uh huh,
because it's fire and grease...splattering all over the place.
So finally we're like, I think it's cooked, let's do this, let's try it
let's eat it. We picked up our fat and we wrapped it in a piece of lettuce
and we're both like...
*chewing sounds*....
Oh...it's very...chewy...mmm...
I still haven't...gotten through yet...
what's that over there? *cough cough*
(Mmm...tissue and threw that away...)
MMmMMmMMM....*bluughhhh*
We felt really embarrassed because we ordered all this meat
and we had all these banchan on the table and we had our water
and we're like, we've literally been here for 10 minutes,
are we really going to abandon all this food? What can we do?
So we came up with a plan. Underneath the table,
I called Simon on my cell phone.  So I was casually like,
*pretending to do nothing....secretly dialling under the table*
So I picked up the phone and I was like, "Hello?"
"What? NO! Really!? OH MY GOD!!!" And then I stood up and I was like,
"This is terrible! This is terrible..." because I really wanted the
restaurant to see me..."oh my god, this is...no, when do you need me to come?"
"right now? You need me to come RIGHT NOW??? OKAY! I'll come RIGHT NOW!!!!"
And then I go over to the waiter I and I'm like, "AHHGHHhhh..umm.."
*blurry arm movements to indicate a quick departure*
We flailed around like we were panicking. And then he understood
because he say there was panic in my face after the phone call.
And bless his heart, he's like, "I'll wrap up all your food for you."
Ohhhh...will you? Sooooo thoughtful...that's soooo kind of you....
And we paid and we rushed out of there...
but now we have a bag of pig fat. Yeah, what do we do with it?
So the problem is, Korea doesn't have a lot of garbage cans--yeah I know!--
Well, the reason is, you have to pay for your garbage bags in Korea,
so if you had a lot of public garbage cans, nobody would pay for a garbage bag.
Soooo, we went to a pay-phone to make a  "phone call"...mmmhmm...
another emergency "phone call"...very emergent...
and we picked up the phone, and we put the meat down and we made our phone call
and we hung up and then we, we walked away and--oops! We forgot our meat!
Oh no! Oh noes! That's too bad...I know, we're terrible people. Yes we are.
BUT I bet the next person that made a phone call was like,
"This...is amazing. This is proof that God exists and that he loves me."
So that's it for this week, if there's a question you want us to answer
for next week's TLDR, leave your question in the Google Moderator page.
Or, if you don't have a question, you can take a look at the questions already asked,
and you can thumb them up or thumb them down
and hope that the one you chose will be voted for next week.
Assah!
GONG!
Sexy intoxication music.

comments.text:
In Christianity Pig is Forbidden than Why are You Eating: 
And the pig, because it parts the hoof and is cloven-footed but does not 
chew the cud, is unclean to you. You shall not eat any of their flesh, and 
you shall not touch their carcasses; they are unclean to you. - Bible 
Leviticus 11:7-8﻿

comments.author: lexiconartist

comments.text:
Are you guys still in Korea? If so are you in Seoul? If so next time I 
visit with my wife would you like to go out for a bite to eat? Yes this is 
a strange thing to ask since we absolutely don't know each other and are 
complete strangers but it would really be a blessing to hang out with other 
Canadians who have an understanding of Korea, even if it is for a short 
while. All my Korean relatives (except one cousin) don't speak English. I 
have a terrific Korean family and love them to pieces, but since I'm still 
learning Korean I miss out on sharing a lot of my experiences. When I visit 
Korea I am always in an ALL Korean neighbourhood, where it is strange to 
see any Western people. Next time I visit it would be great to hang out 
with some Canadians who can relate to my Korean experiences and teach me 
some new ones. Great videos by the way, learned a bunch of stuff I didn't 
know.﻿
comments.author: Colin Heacock

comments.text:
While it's rather unlikely they will be able to meet up with you, they 
along with friends own a cafe in Seoul called "You Are Here". They have 
several videos about it so I won't go into specifics, but basically it 
recently opened and it's for people looking to learn Korean (or vice versa) 
and to just hang out. If you go there, you'll probably be able to meet 
quite a few of their international fans and locals wanting to learn 
English. Good luck on learning English and I hope you have the luck to see 
Simon and Martina at their coffee shop in Seoul!
comments.author: Tiffany D

comments.text:
The worst mistake I made in Korea was not understanding a subtle difference 
in their language that doesn't exist in English. On occasion you will 
encounter two words that are the same. In English when two words are the 
same how we use it in a sentence will tell us what word we mean. This can 
can also be true in Korean (i.e. bridge and leg are the same) but there are 
some instances where placing extra emphasis on the syllables in two words 
that sound the same will change its meaning. In my example I was showing my 
wife's friend's boyfriend a picture of my niece. In Korea niece or nephew 
is called joe-ka. Now if you say the KA hard and loud like I did it changes 
the meaning to fuck you. Yeah don't do this.﻿
comments.author: Colin Heacock

comments.text:
I'm actually quite the "quiet American" stereotype. I try my very hardest 
not to offend or hurt anyone and, even, when I do end up doing so, I feel 
guilty, to the point where sometimes I cry. I was always raised to be 
polite and gracious towards others. I don't appreciate how you're so boldly 
grouping Americans together; it would be like myself grouping you with the 
negative aspects of your Homeland- you certainly wouldn't like it much, 
would you?
comments.author: Purinsu za Rippa

comments.text:
Actually, part of the reason Korea seems to have a vendetta against public 
trash cans was that hobos used to set them on fire for warmth. The 
government wasn't impressed, hence the lack of trash cans. Also, some parts 
of Korea are super-picky about recycling, and they hate it when it gets all 
jumbled up in one pile (Note: do not litter in most areas of Korea. 
Everyone in the street will give you extremely judgemental looks)

comments.text:
Hi Simon and Martina, one question: did you really bbq it fully and used 
the sauce?? because i know that many North American don't eat meat fully 
cooked. pig skin is quite a common food in Asia (to my understanding). most 
importantly--pig skin is rich in collagen which is quite healthy, 
especially for women
comments.author: Half-Blind

comments.text: haha do guys love that now??? i mean i never ate pork.. does it tastes good?
comments.author: luvsachkash

comments.text:
in japan they call it hormone yaki but its mainly leftover meat from pigs, 
chicken and stuff. and i tried eating it at a korean barbeque and it was 
chewy. they do look like chicken for a second. im curious to try this pig 
skin that they were talking about. in the philippines when i eat lechon 
(roasted pig), the skin is hard and crispy.
comments.author: jaysato

comments.text:
i know you're japanese you probably used google translate and got 
"hormones" so i guess its understandable. sorry for the misunderstanding, 
but yeah, we weren't on the same page to begin with.
comments.author: edap

comments.text:
im a japanese. and by the way i dont appreciate random people in the 
internet calling me an idiot. they eat this thing in japan called ホルモン in 
korean bbq and i thought thats what they were referring too. and yes i 
happen to also be half filipino and we eat pig skin.
comments.author: jaysato

comments.text:
no, jok bal is 'pig feet.' the thing simonandmartina are referring to is 
actually pig skin.
